verses.text: Then during the reign of Esar-haddon I returned home, and my wife Anna and my son Tobias were restored to me. At our festival of Pentecost, which is the sacred festival of weeks, a good dinner was prepared for me and I reclined to eat.
verses.comment: Tobit’s return during Esar-haddon’s reign marks a time of restoration for his family; his celebration of Pentecost (Feast of Weeks, cf. Exodus 34:22) highlights the ongoing devotion to Jewish law even in exile.
verses.sectionHeader: Tobit's Burial of the Murdered Israelite

verses.text: When the table was set for me and an abundance of food placed before me, I said to my son Tobias, 'Go, my child, and bring whatever poor person you may find of our people among the exiles in Nineveh, who is wholeheartedly mindful of God, and he shall eat together with me. I will wait for you, until you come back.'
verses.comment: Tobit's invitation shows charity rooted in the law, a virtue advanced by Christ who commanded care for the poor (Matt. 25:35-40). Sharing with the needy is a spiritual act of mercy, reflecting the unity and communal character of the early Church.

verses.text: So Tobias went to look for some poor person of our people. When he had returned he said, 'Father!' And I replied, 'Here I am, my child.' Then he went on to say, 'Look, father, one of our own people has been murdered and thrown into the market place, and now he lies there strangled.'
verses.comment: The neglected dead reflect Israel's suffering in exile and the need for dignity even in death. This concern for the body expresses belief in bodily resurrection and hope, pointing to the physical care shown in Christ's burial (Matt. 27:59-60).

verses.text: I immediately rose from the meal, left the food untouched, and took the body from the marketplace. I laid it in a room until sunset so I could bury it.
verses.comment: Interrupting his feast, Tobit prioritizes mercy and the law, echoing Christ’s teaching of mercy over ritual (Matt. 9:13). Gathering the body prefigures Christian concern for burial and resurrection, bearing the marks of self-giving sacrifice.

verses.text: When I returned, I washed myself and ate my food in sorrow.
verses.comment: Tobit’s ritual washing and eating in sorrow reflect mourning practices, emphasizing his deep compassion and moral distress after burying a fellow Israelite despite personal risk.

verses.text: Then I remembered the prophecy of Amos, how he said against Bethel, 'Your festivals shall be turned into mourning, and all your songs into lamentation.' And I wept.
verses.comment: Remembering Amos 8:10, Tobit draws a parallel between his own mournful feast and the prophet’s warning, illustrating how faithfulness can lead to suffering amid communal apostasy.

verses.text: When the sun had set, I went and dug a grave and buried him.
verses.comment: Tobit’s clandestine burial at sunset demonstrates dedication to Jewish burial customs (cf. Deuteronomy 21:22-23) and highlights his courage to practice righteousness under threat.

verses.text: And my neighbors laughed and said, 'Is he still not afraid? He has already been hunted down to be put to death for doing this, and he ran away; yet here he is again burying the dead!'
verses.comment: The neighbors’ mockery underlines Tobit’s isolation and the social cost of moral conviction, reflecting the tension between faithful Jewish practice and a hostile environment.

verses.text: That same night I washed myself and went into my courtyard and slept by the wall of the courtyard, with my face uncovered because of the heat.
verses.comment: Tobit’s choice to sleep outside after ritual purification may indicate mourning custom or avoidance of ritual impurity, showing his scrupulous observance of the law despite hardship.

verses.text: I did not know that there were sparrows on the wall; their fresh droppings fell into my eyes and produced white films. I went to physicians to be healed, but the more they treated me with ointments, the more my vision was obscured by the white films, until I became completely blind. For four years I remained unable to see. All my kindred were sorry for me, and Ahikar took care of me for two years before he went to Elymais.
verses.comment: The unexpected blindness caused by sparrow droppings introduces divine providence through suffering, foreshadowing later healing and underscoring themes of innocent suffering and reliance on God; parallels Job’s trials.
verses.sectionHeader: Anna Earns a Living and Tobit's Dispute over the Goat

verses.text: She would deliver what she made to the owners, and they would pay her wages.
verses.comment: Honest work and just wages are emphasized as enduring values, upheld later by apostolic teaching (1 Thess. 4:11–12).

verses.text: She used to send what she made to the owners and they would pay wages to her. One day, the seventh of Dystrus, when she cut off a piece she had woven and sent it to the owners, they paid her full wages and also gave her a young goat for a meal.
verses.comment: The mention of the seventh day and gift of a goat highlights the connection to offerings and ritual purity, showing how daily life was intertwined with honoring God.

verses.text: But when she came home, the goat began to bleat. I said to her, 'Where did you get this goat? Is it stolen? Return it to the owners, for we must not eat anything unlawfully taken.'
verses.comment: Tobit's insistence on justice and honesty in even the smallest matter reiterates holiness in daily living. The integrity signaled here speaks to a sacramental view where even the ordinary is consecrated.

verses.text: But she said to me, 'It was given to me as a gift in addition to my wages.' But I did not believe her, and told her to return it to the owners. I became flushed with anger against her over this. Then she replied to me, 'Where are your acts of charity? Where are your righteous deeds? These things are known about you!'
verses.comment: Anna’s defense highlights recognition of good deeds among the community. Authentic righteousness is known by fruit, as Christ taught (Matt. 7:16). Personal conflict teaches humility and the reality of virtue practiced in hidden ways.
